position.marginalia_text: Vt vtriq[ue] historia[e], tam extera[e], quàm Romana[e] accommodata Pra[e]fatio. Rerum Romanarum mej primi historici, Aurelius Victor. Eutropius. Liuius. Exterarum rerum, Justinus, Æmilius Probus, maximam partem Polya[e]nus. Vtrisq[ue] valdè conducunt Florus, Frontinus, Velleius, Valerius Maximus, Plutarchus. Quibus etiam propter res neotericas adiungo Egnatium, Gandinum, Jouium, Guicciardinum. Omninoq[ue] Zuingerum. Nullos pra[e]termitto signiferos, nec Gra[e]cos, nec Latinos, nec vernaculos: sed insisto singulis, mea quadam ad communem, propriúmq[ue] vsum singulari methodo. Nec istam Romanaru[m], exterarúmq[ue] rerum discriminationem, vllus adhuc, quod sciam, Polyhistor, satis accuratè est meditatus. Interest politici, hanc distinctionem subtiliùs decidere: et tot Reru[m]publicaru[m] historicos solertiori iudicio examinare.

marginalia.translation: This preface is also commonly attached to Justin, as it is suitable for each kind of history, both foreign and Roman. My leading historians for Roman matters are Aurelius Victor, Eutropius, and Livy. For foreign matters: Justin, Aemilius Probus and, for the largest part, Polyaenus. Florus, Frontinus, Velleius, Valerius Maximus and Plutarch are very useful for both. And to these I add Egnatius, Gandinus, Giovio, Guicciardini for modern issues, and especially Zwinger. I do not leave out any important ones, whether Greek, Latin, or vernacular, but I devote myself to particular ones, with my own specific method for general and private use. And to my knowledge no polymath so far has reflected in sufficient detail upon this distinction between Roman and foreign matters. It is important for a politician to mark this difference accurately and to analyze the historians of all these Republics with a particularly skillful judgment.

underline.text: sine suo periculo, cautum sapientemq[ue] fieri
